Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that President Obama issued a full pardon for rapper C-Murder.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or official statement from the President or the Department of Justice to confirm the pardon.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that President Obama has the power to pardon C-Murder, even though he was not convicted of a federal crime. The claim fails to consider that the power to pardon for state crimes lies with the Governor of Louisiana.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the Gummy Post article may have been published to coincide with a petition asking the Louisiana Supreme Court to reconsider Miller's appeals and request for a retrial.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting conflicting information and not providing a clear and accurate account of the situation.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the situation by stating that President Obama issued a "full pardon" for C-Murder, when there is no evidence to support this.
Understate: There is no evidence of any understatement bias in the provided claim.
